awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   Deciphering molecular mechanisms underlying liquid-liquid phase separation of ubiquilin proteins
awd_abstract_narration:
Living cells can separate chemical reactions or other functions into separate compartments, or organelles, most of which are surrounded by lipid membranes that form a barrier between the rest of the cell and the organelle.  Membrane-less organelles, instead, are formed by liquid-liquid phase separation (LLPS) of macromolecules (like proteins) that coalesce to form liquid-like droplets and organelles that are not surrounded by lipid membranes. Deciphering the biophysical rules governing the assembly and disassembly of these membrane-less organelles is necessary to understanding their cellular functions. This project will establish ubiquilin proteins as a model system by which the LLPS assembly and disassembly will be studied. Ubiquilins are proteins that regulate protein quality control mechanisms inside cells. The broader impact of this project will lead to the development of a new multiscale approach using nuclear magnetic resonance, small angle scattering, microscopy and computational modeling to study LLPS that can then be extended to other molecular systems. Additionally, the education plan aims to improve science literacy among high school students, broaden STEM representation from economically-disadvantaged and/or underrepresented populations, and develop science teaching and communication skills for STEM graduate students. To accomplish these goals, high school students will participate in a yearly mini-workshop as part of the Summer Science Institute (SSI) at Syracuse University. These students will experiment on how physical parameters (e.g. temperature) modulate LLPS of proteins, the results of which will be integrated into the project's scientific goals.

The research project is focused on elucidating the molecular determinants of the liquid-liquid phase separation of ubiquilin proteins, specifically UBQLN1, UBQLN2 and UBQLN4. UBQLNs are a relevant model system for studying LLPS because both intrinsically-disordered regions and folded domains in UBQLN2 modulate its LLPS. The project's goals are to: (1) investigate the role of protein oligomerization in promoting phase separation of UBQLN proteins using deletion constructs, NMR spectroscopy, and microscopy, and (2) use small-angle X-ray and neutron scattering (SAXS, SANS) to look inside protein droplets, and structurally characterize the phase-separated and non-phase separated states with computational modeling. Execution of this project will directly contribute to the PI's long-term goal of building a comprehensive model of LLPS.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this CAREER program was to use a multi-scale approach to determine the molecular origins for the phase separation of ubiquilins (UBQLNs), a class of proteins that maintain protein quality control in our cells. Phase separation is hypothesized to be a mechanism that underlies how liquid-like membraneless organelles (or biomolecular condensates) form inside cells; these condensates assemble and disassemble in response to environmental and signaling cues. After our discovery that UBQLN2 phase separates under physiological conditions in vitro and forms stress-induced condensates in cells, we proposed UBQLNs to be an ideal protein model system for determining the biophysical rules driving phase separation.

Intellectual Merit:

We engineered libraries of full-length UBQLNs and protein domain deletion constructs to dissect the individual contributions of domains to phase separation. We found that both well-ordered domains (UBL, UBA) and intrinsically-disordered regions contributed interactions to drive phase separation. One of these disordered regions is the disease-linked proline-rich region in UBQLN2. Using microscopy, modeling, size-exclusion chromatography, small angle-scattering, and multi-angle light scattering, we found that the ability of UBQLNs to self-associate and oligomerize was coupled to an increased ability to phase separate. The significance of this finding is that additional protein systems have been identified where oligomerization is linked to phase separation. We combined biomolecular NMR spectroscopy and temperature-concentration phase diagrams for 95 amino acid substitutions to determine the specific amino acid positions (stickers) that drive phase separation of UBQLN2. Hydrophobic and polar amino acids at sticker positions promoted phase separation, whereas similar substitutions at spacer positions had minimal effects. Our experimental observations supported the stickers and spacers framework that is now used to describe the molecular grammar of many other macromolecular phase-separating systems.

Through innovations in making full-length UBQLNs for biochemical study, we found that the short, disordered, N-terminal region of UBQLNs (10-30 amino acids) dictates the differences in phase separation for the three human UBQLN paralogs: full-length UBQLN1 / UBQLN2 / UBQLN4. Consequently, fusions of N-terminal epitope tags to UBQLNs significantly altered their phase separation profiles, but in a predictable manner consistent with the molecular grammar of UBQLNs we discovered recently. These findings are impactful for both the molecular biophysics and cell biology communities as care must be taken in evaluating the impact of commonly-used epitope tags fused to target proteins when studying biomolecular condensates in cells.

This grant mechanism has enabled us to expand beyond microscopy and small angle scattering approaches to new structural biology methods such as ion-mobility mass spectrometry (IMMS). We used IMMS to examine protein conformations under conditions that approach phase separation. With new collaborators (Rebecca Beveridge), we identified that the conformation of UBQLN2 becomes more extended under conditions that favor phase separation, whereas the conformation of UBQLN2 becomes compact upon binding ubiquitin (a condition that disfavors phase separation).

Overall, this NSF CAREER project resulted in 11 publications, several highlights in journals, and many seminar presentations at national and international conferences.

Broader Impacts

This project had significant impact on the training of scientists from underrepresented populations in STEM across multiple levels ranging from high school to the postdoctoral scholar. Specifically, this project provided research opportunities for >20 high school students, 5 undergraduates at SU, and 5 undergraduates at Onondaga Community College (OCC). Of these students, several are now in PhD graduate programs and at least one was awarded an NSF GRFP fellowship. We ran a high school workshop that trained students on expressing and purifying protein for phase separation studies. Due to the pandemic, we piloted a new program with OCC to bring ~10 community college students/yr for a one-week lab internship during the winter intersession. The success of this program (now named uSure) led to an OCC-led NSF proposal that was recently funded.

Additionally, three graduate students (two PhD, one MS) and one postdoctoral scholar were supported by this project. All are in STEM positions at biotech companies or at academia (postdoc). Each of these students had successful traineeships with multiple in-person oral presentations at national meetings and first-author publications in high-impact journals.

We established a new undergraduate/graduate course in the Biology curriculum titled Droplets and Gels in Healthy and Diseased Cells with a major emphasis on learning how to put together and present 10-minute journal club-style oral talks through multiple practices. Aside from developing scientific communications skills, this course further emphasizes rigor in reading and analyzing recent scientific literature on the physical principles of biomolecular condensate assembly/disassembly. A special feature of this class enables students to meet three-four authors/semester through either in-person or zoom-based meetings to discuss the writing and peer review processes.
